title: Post-Traumatic Hemiparesis in a Young Adult Following Severe TBI
clinical_history: Jonathan is a 27-year-old male who suffered a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) six months ago as a result of a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He was an unrestrained passenger. He was initially comatose for two weeks and required a prolonged ICU admission with neurosurgical intervention for an acute subdural hematoma (right frontoparietal craniotomy). He is currently attending outpatient neurorehabilitation with ongoing left-sided hemiparesis and increased tone (spasticity), affecting, in particular, his left upper and lower limb. He complains of persistent muscle tightness in his left arm (biceps, wrist flexors) and left leg (quadriceps, hamstrings, and calf muscles). He also reports diffuse, aching left shoulder pain (likely subluxation and secondary immobility) and lesser intermittent headaches. Jonathan has moderate difficulty in ADLs and ambulates short distances with a cane, with significant foot drop and circumduction on the left.

nprs.affected_area: left glenohumeral joint with muscle spasticity (mainly deltoid, supraspinatus, biceps)

aggrevating_factors: Passive or active movement of the left upper limb (especially during therapy); prolonged standing or ambulation; carrying objects with affected side.
picture: [image suggestion: individual with visible left hemiparesis, holding affected arm in flexed position, left foot in slight equinovarus].
easing_factors: Proper limb support (shoulder sling), regular passive stretching, hot packs to shoulder/thigh, scheduled muscle relaxants, rest.
past_history: Previously healthy; no significant premorbid musculoskeletal or neurological issues. No prior psychiatric history.
medical_history: History significant for hypertension, diagnosed post-injury; currently controlled. No known diabetes or cardiac issues.
medications: Baclofen 10mg tid (for spasticity), Paracetamol 500mg prn (for pain), Lisinopril 5mg od (for blood pressure).
personal_history: Works as a graphic designer; unmarried; lives with parents for now. Nonsmoker; no substance use. Previously independent in all activities. Expresses frustration and decreased motivation post-injury, with occasional mild depressive symptoms.
imaging: Recent MRI brain (3 months ago): chronic right frontoparietal gliosis and encephalomalacia; left shoulder X-ray: mild inferior subluxation, no fracture
